analyzed: 'di bzhin du rigs pa spos te dpyad na gzugs med pa rnam pa brgyad yod do snyam du sems so //

analyzed: 'di nas brtsams te mya ngan las 'das pa dang / rgyu dang / 'bras bu thams cad stong par mthong zhing ming tsam du zad kyi /

original: ye nas chad pa'o //

original: zhes smra'o // 'di ltar shi ba'i 'og tu gzugs med do //
analyzed: zhes smra'o // 'di ltar shi ba'i 'og tu gzugs med do //

analyzed: zhes phyin ci log tu smra ba'i mu stegs can zhes bya'o //
translated: Here, among the five aggregates, one is called a tīrthika who speaks falsely, saying, “After death there is no form.”

analyzed: so sor 'jig par mthong la /

translated: He says, “After death, form is both existent and nonexistent.”🔽Moreover, he examines the nature of all compounded things, which is to change and deceive. He generates the superknowledges, and realizes that all existents are neither existent nor nonexistent. He grasps the measure of the emptiness of reality.

original: byang chub kyi lam ni /

analyzed: gol te / 'di la dgu pa shi ba'i 'og tu phung po lnga chad par lta ba'i phyin ci log gi mu stegs can zhes bya'o //
translated: This is called the extreme of the nihilistic extremists who view the five aggregates as being blocked after death.

analyzed: skye ba'i rigs kyi rtsa ba mthar thug par dpyad de /

analyzed: zhes bka' stsal lags na /
translated: “The Bhagavān has said that the five signs of the aggregates are the root of the five false perceptions.

analyzed: bdag cag sngon chad de bzhin gshegs pas 'di ltar zab cing phra bar phye ste bstan pa thos par ma gyur lags /

analyzed: yang phung po 'di gcig car du zhi zhing zad par 'gyur ram /

analyzed: de bzhin gshegs pas thugs rje chen pos dgongs te 'khor 'dus pa 'di dag la yid dang mig shin tu dvangs shing /

analyzed: gdod ma nas rnam par dag pa ste /

analyzed: skye shi dang rdul gyi dri ma thams cad yod pa ma yin zhing /

analyzed: 'di nas bzung ste nam mkha' stong pa'i bar thams cad kyang phyin ci log gi 'du @591b shes kyis bskyed pa yin la /
translated: From this point onward, all of space and emptiness are created by mistaken conceptualization.

original: de'i tshul ni /
analyzed: de'i tshul ni /

analyzed: rmad du byung ba'i gsal rig rnam par dag pa las yang dag pa ma yin pa'i snod kyi 'jig rten thams cad skye'o //

analyzed: a'a dzny'a ta ti 'khrul nas grib ma la yid ches pa lta bu ste /

analyzed: yang dag pa ma yin pa la gdod ma nas rgyu med do //

analyzed: phyin ci log gi 'du shes pa las rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba'i mtshan nyid rnam par bzhag ste /
translated: The characteristics of dependent origination are established on the basis of the notion of error.

analyzed: rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba la 'khrul na rang byung du smra'o //
translated: If one errs in regard to dependent origination, one will speak of spontaneous origination.

analyzed: stong pa'i rang bzhin de yang yang dag pa ma yin pa las byung zhing /
translated: The nature of emptiness arises from what is unreal.

analyzed: rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba dang rang byung ba zhes bya ba thams cad sems can rnams kyi yang dag pa ma yin pa'i sems kyis gdags pa'o //
translated: All that is called dependent origination and spontaneous origination is designated by the unreal minds of sentient beings.

original: kun dga' bo /
analyzed: kun dga' bo /

analyzed: yang dag pa ma yin pas de dag byas par shes na yang dag pa ma yin pa'i rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba smra'o //
translated: if one understands that they are created by the unreal, one speaks of the dependent origination of the unreal.

translated: If you understand that what is not real has never existed, you will realize that what is not real—dependent arising—has never existed at all.

original: de ltar mi shes pa dag gis rang byung du smra ba lta ci smos /
analyzed: de ltar mi shes pa dag gis rang byung du smra ba lta ci smos /
translated: So what need is there to mention that those who do not understand this will speak of self-arising?

analyzed: de'i phyir de bzhin gshegs pas khyed cag la phung po lnga po thams cad yang dag pa ma yin pa'i 'du shes kyi rtsa ba'i rgyu las byung bar @592a *//
translated: Therefore, the Tathāgata has clearly taught you that all five aggregates arise from the root cause, which is the conception of what is not real.

original: gsal bar bstan to //
analyzed: gsal bar bstan to //
translated: He has taught you this.

original: khyod kyis lus ni /
analyzed: khyod kyis lus ni /

analyzed: sngon pha ma'i 'du shes kyis rgyu byas pa las byung ba yin zhing khyod kyi 'du shes ni /

analyzed: de lta ma yin na skye srid du 'ong bar mi nus te /
translated: Your conception cannot arise without them.

analyzed: 'di ltar na 'du shes brgyud nas srog thob par 'gyur ro //
translated: In this way, you obtain life through the continuity of conception.

analyzed: dper na / ngas sngar smras pa bzhin sems la ro skyur po bsam na 'gram chu ldang la /

analyzed: ci'i phyir ro skyur po gleng pa na 'gram chu ldang / de'i phyir tshul 'di shes par gyis shig /
translated: So understand this method:

analyzed: tshor ba'i rkyen gyi dbang gis lus g-yo bar nus so //
translated: then the perception of a feeling can make your body move.

analyzed: sna tshogs pa'i rnam pa 'char bar 'gyur /

analyzed: kun tu 'jug pa'i yang dag pa ma yin pa'i 'du shes te /

analyzed: gsum pa'o // 'gyur ba'i rang bzhin sdod pa med par skad cig skad cig gis mi mngon par 'pho bas rim gyis san mo dang skra skye ba dang zungs nyams shing gdong la gnyer ma byung bdag nyin mtshan rgyun mi 'chad par rgyug kyang shes shing tshor bar mi 'gyur ro
translated: The nature of change is that you do not stay still but move imperceptibly from moment to moment. Gradually, hair grows on your body and head, your skin withers and wrinkles appear on your face, and you run day and night without knowing or feeling it.

analyzed: // kun dga' bo /
translated: Ānanda,

analyzed: gal te de ltar ma yin na khyod kyi lus ci'i phyir 'gyur bar snang /

translated: Therefore, all perceptions

analyzed: te; bzhi pa'o //

analyzed: gal te yang dag pa'i rang bzhin ni /
translated: If the true nature

translated: Why is it that after seeing something amazing in the past, you forget it after a long time has passed, and then later, when you suddenly see it again, you recognize it as it was before, without confusion or forgetfulness?

analyzed: des na gsal ba'i rang bzhin rtag brtan mi g-yo ba las dran pa'i bag chags rgyun du 'jug pas bsam du ci zhig yod /

analyzed: rtag brtan 'di yang dag pa ma yin par shes par gyis shig /

analyzed: bltas pa na mi g-yo ba ltar snang yang de ni / myur bar rgyu ba ma mthong ba yin gyi /
translated: When you look at it, it seems to be still,🔽but it is not that it is not moving;

analyzed: mi rgyu ba ma yin no //
translated: it is just that you do not see it moving quickly.

analyzed: ci ste 'du shes rtsa ba ma yin na rdzun pa'i bag chags ji ltar bsgo /

original: khyod kyi dbang po drug ni /
analyzed: khyod kyi dbang po drug ni /

analyzed: phan tshun du 'pho zhing spyod de phye zhing sbyor bar ma nus na /
translated: are mutually transforming and functioning. If they cannot be separated and combined,

analyzed: phyin ci @593b log gi 'du shes 'di 'gag pa'i dus med do //
translated: then there is no time for the cessation of this inverted perception.

translated: From the pure and clear, the profound and subtle inverted perception of mere false appearances arises—this is the fifth.

original: kun dga' bo /
analyzed: kun dga' bo /
translated: Ānanda,

analyzed: nye bar len pa'i phung po lnga po 'di yang dag pa ma yin pa'i 'du shes lnga las grub pa ste /

analyzed: khyod da lta phung po'i mtha' zab pa dang mi zab pa shes par 'dod na /
